I Work as a butcher, i was born in a 3rd world country (honduras) this  type of slaughtering is close to how we do stuff where i'm from, it takes practice and finesse to slaughter an animal and while where i'm from this death is quick, we don't like to make it suffer to much, a lot of places do because they feel that the adrenaline released will change the flavor of the meat (making it sweeter and tender) this isn't the case, in fact the chemicals released in the fight or flight response actually cause the meat to become very tough, similar to how your body will become tense after a very stressful adrenaline filled activity. these hormones and the adrenaline will actually cause the meat to become a tiny bit more acidic as it raises the PH levels inside the meat, fat etc. as a butcher we are taught basically that an animal who dies happy means that the meat will bring back a happy customer, a happy death means less stress hormones, softer sweeter meat and also means that the animal will pass away with less pain and less fear  stress is short-term, the changed chemistry within the meat make the meat tough and causes it to lose flavor. But if stress persists for an extended period of time, the meat becomes dark, soft, mushy and sticky (called dark cutters), like bruised meat, and will have a very limited shelf life. The persistent high acidity in the meat caused by long-term  stress will actually begin breaking down the meat over time, almost as if the body is digesting itself. And it is also hard on the animals vital organs like the liver and kidney, which have to process these fairly aggressive chemicals and expel the waste products. Yuck.  smarter everyday, humane practices and fair animal treatment = tastier meat. tastes good to be empathetic (not that killing the animal period is a better option)
